Indonesian.name: Asesmen Komunikasi untuk Leader-Managers
Indonesian.instructions: Silakan membaca pertanyaan dengan seksama. Jawablah dengan jujur dan hanya anda yang bisa melihat hasilnya.

feedback.text: Superstar Communicator. Keep on doing all the right things and take a look at those areas you scored yourself less than 5 and determine how to raise those scores.

Talented Communicator. Identify the areas you need to improve. Determine which one, if improved, would have the biggest impact on your success. What behavior can you start to practice to improve the skill?

Mediocre Communicator. Seek out advice from communications superstar in your organization. Create a development plan that focuses on the top two skills you need to improve. Ask for feedback and coaching from this person as you implement the plan.

Distressed Communicator. Ask for assistance from your manager to develop an improvement plan including any necessary communications training. Track progress of the plan and make necessary changes if improvement isn’t being observed by your manager.

Bankrupt Communicator. Remedial work is required, ask someone you trust who is a superstar or talented communicator to help coach you. If improvement isn’t made, you may want to seek outside advice on your career plans. It may be that becoming a manager-leader is outside your grasp and you need to re- evaluate your career goals.

questions.prompt: I do not have someone else discipline, coach or do performance reviews for my team members. I do all of that myself.
I ask probing and open ended questions to understand a situation before giving my advice or opinion.
When I listen to my team members, it is important for me to be empathetic. I allow them to talk without having to feel that they are being criticized or judged.

I do not give my team members mixed messages. I would not say: 'Thanks for finishing the project on time; it will save us a lot of money. But, while working on a project, you need to communicate your status more often.'
When I listen, I try to clarify what my team members have said. I do this to let them know that I am actively listening to what they are saying.
I keep an open mind and try to understand the point of view of other team members.
When listening, I give my full attention to my team members. I am not on the phone, writing or thinking about something else.
I summarize what I have heard and understood at the end of a conversation or discussion.
I am careful not to allow the words or expressions that I use to get in the way of my team members understanding me. I avoid jargon, slang, and acronyms.
When I listen, I look for meaning by listening to what my team members say, their vocal tones and inflections and by watching their facial expressions, hand gestures, and body language.
I am aware that team members come from different backgrounds and diverse cultures, so they communicate differently. I adapt my communication styles to meet their needs.
I communicate my feelings and thoughts about work issues and policies to my team members.
I make it a point to give my team members positive feedback often.
I am very specific when I am describing what team members did well or what they need improvement in. I would not use a general, vague statement like, 'You have a bad attitude.'
I give constructive feedback in private.
I give positive or constructive feedback as soon after an event as possible.
I give performance and constructive feedback in person and not electronically (email or text) or by phone.
I am aware of my personal body language, verbal tones and inflections when communicating and will make adjustments to increase the effectiveness of my communications.
I can speak confidently in a group setting and am able to model the communication needs of group members.
When coaching a team member, I ask questions to get them to create their own solution and I don’t direct them to my solution.
